infodynamics.measures.continuous.kraskov
Class MultiInfoCalculatorKraskov

java.lang.Object
  infodynamics.measures.continuous.kraskov.MultiInfoCalculatorKraskov
All Implemented Interfaces:
MultiInfoCalculator
Direct Known Subclasses:
MultiInfoCalculatorKraskov1, MultiInfoCalculatorKraskov2
public abstract class MultiInfoCalculatorKraskov
extends java.lang.Object
implements MultiInfoCalculator

Compute the Multi-Information (or integration) using the Kraskov estimation method. Two child classes actually implement the two algorithms in the Kraskov paper.

Author:
Joseph Lizier
See Also:
"Estimating mutual information", Kraskov, A., Stogbauer, H., Grassberger, P., Physical Review E 69, (2004) 066138, http://dx.doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.69.066138

setProperty

public void setProperty(java.lang.String propertyName,
                        java.lang.String propertyValue)
Sets properties for the calculator. Valid properties include:
  • PROP_K - number of neighbouring points in joint kernel space
  • PROP_NORM_TYPE
    • - normalization type to apply to working out the norms between the points in each marginal space. Options are defined by EuclideanUtils.setNormToUse(String) - default is EuclideanUtils.NORM_MAX_NORM.
  • PROP_TRY_TO_KEEP_ALL_PAIRS_NORM)

Specified by:
setProperty in interface MultiInfoCalculator

startIndividualObservations

public void startIndividualObservations()
User elects to set observations one by one rather than in one go. Will need to call endIndividualObservations before calling any of the compute functions, otherwise the previous observations will be used.

computeAverageLocalOfObservations

                                                  throws java.lang.Exception
Specified by:
computeAverageLocalOfObservations in interface MultiInfoCalculator

java.lang.Exception

computeAverageLocalOfObservations

public abstract double computeAverageLocalOfObservations(int[][] reordering)
                                                  throws java.lang.Exception
Compute what the average MI would look like were all time series reordered as per the array of time indices in reordering. The reordering array contains the reordering for each marginal variable (first index). The user should ensure that all values 0..N-1 are represented exactly once in the array reordering and that no other values are included here.

Parameters:
reordering - the specific new orderings to use. First index is the variable number (minus 1, since we don't reorder the first variable), second index is the time step, the value is the reordered time step to use for that variable at the given time step.
Returns:
Throws:
java.lang.Exception

computeSignificance

public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int numPermutationsToCheck)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
Compute the significance of the multi-information of the previously supplied observations. We destroy the p(x,y,z,..) correlations, while retaining the p(x), p(y),.. marginals, to check how significant this multi-information actually was. This is in the spirit of Chavez et. al., "Statistical assessment of nonlinear causality: application to epileptic EEG signals", Journal of Neuroscience Methods 124 (2003) 113-128 which was performed for Transfer entropy.

Parameters:
numPermutationsToCheck -
Returns:
the proportion of MI scores from the distribution which have higher or equal MIs to ours.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception

computeSignificance

public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int[][][] newOrderings)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
Compute the significance of the mutual information of the previously supplied observations. We destroy the p(x,y,z,..) correlations, while retaining the p(x), p(y),.. marginals, to check how significant this mutual information actually was. This is in the spirit of Chavez et. al., "Statistical assessment of nonlinear causality: application to epileptic EEG signals", Journal of Neuroscience Methods 124 (2003) 113-128 which was performed for Transfer entropy.

Parameters:
newOrderings - the specific new orderings to use. First index is the reordering index, second index is the variable number (minus 1, since we don't reorder the first variable), third index is the reordered variable number for that position.
Returns:
the proportion of MI scores from the distribution which have higher or equal MIs to ours.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception

reorderedTimeStepsForEachMarginal

protected int[] reorderedTimeStepsForEachMarginal(int[][] reordering,
                                                  int timeStep)
Utility to take a reordering matrix and return the array of reordered time indices from which to find the reordered data to be inserted at timeStep.

Parameters:
reordering - the specific new orderings to use. First index is the variable number (can be for all variables, or one less than all if the first is not to be reordered), second index is the time step, the value is the reordered time step to use for that variable at the given time step. If null, no reordering is performed.
timeStep -
Returns:
